title: Fragment

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of wool (camelid), plain weave of discontinuous warps and wefts; embroidered in double running stitches; edged with cross-knit loop stitches.

artist_display:
Nazca or Wari
Peru, south coast, Nazca Valley, Tunga
description: Geometric patterns are common in Andean textile art. Although it may appear simple at first look, this panel is far more elaborate than meets the eye: the geometric designs presented here were formed using multiple techniques, with the weaving of the blue and red half-step frets, the outlining in white embroidery, and the edging in cross-knit loop stitches. This pattern creates an overall checkerboard of color, with the juxtaposed colored surfaces further combining to create full-step frets.
medium_display: Wool (camelid), plain weave of discontinuous warps and wefts; embroidered in double running stitches; edged with cross-knit loop stitches
credit_line: Purchased with funds provided by Mrs. Henry G. Barkhausen
publication_history: Jane W. Rehl, Weaving Metaphors, Weaving Cosmos:  Structure, Creativity and Meaning in Discontinuous Warp and Weft Textiles of Ancient Peru, 300 B.C.E.-1540 C.E. (Ph.D. diss., Emory University, 2003), 647, cat. 142, fig. 142.
exhibition_history:
Art Gallery of the University of Notre Dame, Art of Ancient Peru, December 20, 1961-January 28, 1962

Durham, Woman's College Library of Duke University, Art and Artifacts of Pre-Columbian Peru, December 17, 1964-January 20, 1965

Art Institute of Chicago, Elizabeth F. Cheney and Agnes Allerton Textile Galleries, Mexican, Central, and South American Textiles: A Living Legacy, Oct. 28, 1992-Jan. 17, 1993.

Art Institute of Chicago, Department of Africa, Oceania, and the Americas, May 10- Oct. 27, 1994.

Art Institute of Chicago, Department of African and Amerindian Art, Jan. 29- Mar.24, 1998.

Art Institute of Chicago, Department of African and Amerindian Art, Feb. 7- July 5, 2001.

Art Institute of Chicago, Department of African and Amerindian Art, Aug.- Nov. 23, 2005.

 Art Institute of Chicago, Department of African and Amerindian Art, May 21-Sept. 23, 2014.
provenance_text: Pablo Soldi, Ica, Peru, by 1956 [Incoming Receipt RX2032 dated 10/26/1956 in curatorial file]; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1956.
